awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Investigations of Adiabatic Shear Localization in Materials with Mesoscale Heterogeneities
awd_abstract_narration:
Progress in critical technologies is often enabled by advances in development of new materials, an important class of which is high-performance structural materials. The primary function of these materials is to withstand severe mechanical loads, often in harsh environments, with minimal weight. This award supports fundamental research to develop new and relatively unexplored materials in which the mesoscale structure of materials can be rationally designed to result in superior performance. The project will advance future materials design strategies for dynamic loading applications, examples of which include high speed impact of protective armor, explosive loading of structures, and high-speed machining, thereby advancing national health, prosperity, and welfare; and securing national defense. The fundamental materials design principles that will emerge from this research can be exploited by modern additive manufacturing technologies in manufacturing materials with rationally designed mesoscale architectures. In addition, the award supports educational activities for undergraduate students who will work in multidisciplinary teams to develop short educational animations and disseminate scientific discoveries in a manner accessible to middle and high school students. The award also supports development of educational modules for an outreach program at Brown University that serves students from underrepresented groups in science and technology. 

The research program focuses on understanding the role of mesoscale heterogeneities in the formation and propagation of adiabatic shear bands (ASB), which are an important mechanism by which materials and structures subjected to dynamic loading often fail catastrophically. The research aims to experimentally investigate the mechanics of how a propagating ASB interacts with a controlled heterogeneity through in situ high-speed microscopy, which is a new technique capable of high spatial (up to 0.7 micrometer) and temporal (250 nsec) resolutions simultaneously. When a propagating ASB encounters a heterogeneity of controlled geometry and properties, there are several possible outcomes: the ASB can get arrested, deflected or continue to propagate through and across the heterogeneity. Through in-situ measurement of the transient deformation fields during such interactions, the research seeks to determine the conditions under which each outcome prevails. Computational simulations of ASB-heterogeneity interactions will be carried out to interpret the experimental results, guide the experimental design with respect to the choice of material properties and geometry of the heterogeneities, and develop a predictive capability to help design more complex mesoscale architectures. The new fundamental knowledge gained from these studies can help develop novel mesoscale architectures with significantly enhanced resistance to ASB.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
When structures are subjected to extreme loading conditions such as high speed impact, the material undergoes dynamic damage and failure through a variety of mechanisms such as adiabatic shear banding (ASB) or dynamic crack propagation, spall, etc. As such, there is an ever increasing demand for better structural materials that are lighter and more resistent to extreme loading conditions. The traditional approach for structural alloy development has been through metallurgical approaches, i.e., selecting an appropriate composition and heat treatment that would result in an alloy with certain microstructure (grains, precipitates, nano-phases, etc.) with the corresponding mechanical properties. In contrast, here we envision a new structural materials design strategy in which materials are fabricated with engineered meso-scale architectures that would result in superior mechanical properties. We employ modern multi-material additive manufacturing methods for fabricating such materials. At the same, the meso-scale architected materials development requires parallel progress in high speed diagnostic techniques so that the details of the dynamic failure events at the meso-scale can be imaged at an unprecedented spatial and temporal resolutions simultaneously. 

As part of this project, we have progress on three specific tasks: (i) Development of a high speed microscopy technique for imaging dynamic events at high spatial and temporal resolutions simultaneously. The technique is capable of achieving a temporal resolution of 250 ns and a spatial resolution of 0.5 um, while still having a fairly large field of view (e.g. 1.1 mm x 0.6mm at a spatial resolution of 1 um). It employs a rotating mirror type high speed camera with custom-developed microscope optics and pulsed laser illumination. We have successfully demonstrated the measurement capability by imaging initiation and propagation of adiabatic shear band phenomenon at at notch tip in a polycarbonate specimen subjected to impact loading. The strain field during the initiation and propagation of the shear band was extracted through a particle tracking method at an unprecedented resolution. The experiments were complemented by computational simulations to explain the features of the observations such as formation of multiple localization bands in front of a notch tip. (ii) Development of a thermomechanical constitutive theory for materials under extreme environments: In order to simulate extreme events such as adiabatic shear bands in structural materials, reliable material models are essential that can realistically capture the mechanical behavior under high strain rates, high pressures and high temperatures. A thermodynamically-consistent constitutive model is developed to capture the thermoelastic and thermo-viscoplastic response of solids. A complete Mie-Gruneisen equation of state is employed to model the volumetric behavior while the deviatoric response is captured through a modified Johnson-Cook Model. The material model has been shown to capture experimental observations of dynamic strength and is capable of predicting localization in the form of adiabatic shear bands. (iii)  Development of a multi-metal additive manufacturing method to create structural metals with engineered heterogeneities at a fine spatial resolution.  In order to demonstrate the basic concept, model meso-scale architectures consisting of  lamellar and cross-lamellar architectures were fabricated. Fracture experiments conducted on specimens revealed that meso-architected specimens have toughness enhancement that exceeds the rule of mixtures limit; and for an identical composition, different meso-architectures have different toughnesses, indicating the existence of optimal meso-architectures. These findings open up a wide materials design space in which meso-scale architecture can be optimized for designing materials that can resist extreme loadingn events.  

 

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Pradeep R Guduru
